words.meaning: Not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings or other aspects of something; out of place.
examples: The modern glass skyscraper looked incongruous next to the historic stone church.
His cheerful smile was incongruous with the somber mood of the funeral.

words.meaning: Not important or significant.
examples: The details he was arguing about were completely inconsequential to the main issue.
They spent the afternoon discussing inconsequential matters.

words.meaning: The quality of being changeable and unreliable; fickleness.
examples: Her inconstancy in friendships meant she had few long-term companions.
The inconstancy of the weather made it difficult to plan the outdoor wedding.

words.meaning: Not able to be denied or disputed.
examples: The DNA evidence provided incontrovertible proof of his guilt.
It is an incontrovertible fact that the Earth is round.

words.meaning: To take in or contain (something) as part of a whole; include.
examples: We will incorporate your feedback into the final version of the report.
The new car design incorporates several advanced safety features.

words.meaning: (Of a person or their tendencies) not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed.
examples: He was an incorrigible optimist, always seeing the bright side of things.
The student's incorrigible habit of talking in class led to his detention.

words.meaning: (Of a person or their manner) unwilling or unable to believe something.
examples: She gave him an incredulous stare when he claimed he'd seen a UFO.
He was incredulous at the news of his unexpected lottery win.

words.meaning: The process of keeping something at the right temperature and under the right conditions so it can develop.
examples: The incubation period for this virus is approximately two weeks.
Successful incubation of the chicken eggs requires a constant temperature.

words.meaning: To instill (an attitude, idea, or habit) by persistent instruction.
examples: The coach tried to inculcate a sense of discipline and teamwork in his players.
It is the parents' job to inculcate values like honesty in their children.

words.meaning: Necessary for (someone) as a duty or responsibility; currently holding office.
examples: It is incumbent upon all citizens to vote in the election.
The incumbent mayor is running for a second term.

words.meaning: An invasion or attack, especially a sudden or brief one.
examples: The army was prepared to repel any military incursion into their territory.
There was a sudden incursion of ants into our kitchen.

words.meaning: Owing gratitude for a service or favor.
examples: I am deeply indebted to you for your kindness and support during a difficult time.
She felt forever indebted to the stranger who had saved her dog.

words.meaning: Not in keeping with good taste and propriety; improper.
examples: His indecorous jokes were inappropriate for the formal dinner party.
Shouting during the solemn ceremony was highly indecorous.

words.meaning: (Of a person or their efforts) persisting tirelessly.
examples: She was an indefatigable fundraiser for the children's hospital.
His indefatigable spirit was an inspiration to the entire team.

words.meaning: Not able to be forgotten or removed.
examples: The tragic events of that day left an indelible mark on his soul.
Her visit to the Grand Canyon was an indelible experience.

words.meaning: Not exactly known, established, or defined.
examples: He was sentenced to an indeterminate period of three to five years in prison.
The artist's work is of an indeterminate style, blending several influences.

words.meaning: A period of unseasonably warm, dry weather that sometimes occurs in autumn.
examples: We enjoyed a beautiful Indian summer in late October, with sunny days perfect for hiking.
The unexpected Indian summer gave the farmers more time to harvest their crops.

words.meaning: To formally accuse of or charge with a serious crime.
examples: The grand jury is expected to indict the former executive on charges of fraud.
He was indicted for his alleged involvement in the conspiracy.

words.meaning: A formal charge or accusation of a serious crime; a thing that serves to condemn.
examples: The grand jury issued an indictment against the company for tax evasion.
The high unemployment rate is a sad indictment of the government's economic policies.

words.meaning: Lack of interest, concern, or sympathy.
examples: His complete indifference to her suffering was what hurt the most.
She feigned indifference, but secretly she was anxious about the result.

words.meaning: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.
examples: He was indifferent to politics and never voted.
Sadly, many people are indifferent to the plight of endangered species.

words.meaning: A state of extreme poverty; destitution.
examples: The charity works to relieve indigence in developing countries.
Born into indigence, he worked hard to become a successful businessman.

words.meaning: Originating or occurring naturally in a particular place; native.
examples: The Maori are the indigenous people of New Zealand.
This type of cactus is indigenous to the desert regions of North America.

words.meaning: Poor; needy.
examples: The local shelter provides food and housing for indigent individuals.
The legal aid society offers free services to indigent clients.

words.meaning: Feeling or showing anger or annoyance at what is perceived as unfair treatment.
examples: She wrote an indignant letter to the editor about the misleading article.
He was indignant at being wrongly accused of theft.

words.meaning: Anger or annoyance provoked by what is perceived as unfair treatment.
examples: The news of the corruption scandal was met with public indignation.
She was filled with indignation at the blatant injustice of the verdict.

words.meaning: Done at random or without careful judgment.
examples: The dictator's regime was known for its indiscriminate violence against its own people.
The indiscriminate use of antibiotics can lead to resistant bacteria.

words.meaning: Absolutely necessary.
examples: A reliable internet connection is indispensable for anyone working from home.
He made himself indispensable to the company with his unique skills.

words.meaning: To teach (a person or group) to accept a set of beliefs uncritically.
examples: The totalitarian regime tried to indoctrinate the youth with its state-sponsored propaganda.
Cults often indoctrinate their new members to ensure their complete loyalty.

words.meaning: Wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy.
examples: He spent an indolent afternoon napping in the hammock.
Her indolent habits prevented her from achieving her goals.

words.meaning: Impossible to subdue or defeat.
examples: The small country had an indomitable spirit and refused to surrender.
She faced her illness with indomitable courage.

words.meaning: To succeed in persuading or influencing (someone) to do something; to bring about.
examples: No amount of money could induce him to compromise his principles.
The doctor decided to induce labor as the baby was overdue.

words.meaning: To allow oneself to enjoy the pleasure of something.
examples: After a long week, she decided to indulge in a relaxing bubble bath.
It's okay to indulge your craving for chocolate every once in a while.

words.meaning: Diligent and hard-working.
examples: The industrious student consistently earned top grades.
Bees are known for being industrious insects.

words.meaning: Drunk; intoxicated.
examples: He was arrested for driving while inebriated.
The party guests became loud and inebriated as the night progressed.

words.meaning: Too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words.
examples: The beauty of the northern lights was ineffable.
She felt a sense of ineffable joy at the birth of her first child.

words.meaning: Not producing any or the desired effect.
examples: His attempts to repair the broken vase were ineffectual.
The prime minister was criticized for his ineffectual leadership during the crisis.

words.meaning: Unable to be resisted or avoided; inescapable.
examples: He was facing the ineluctable consequences of his poor decisions.
The ineluctable passage of time waits for no one.

words.meaning: Having or showing no skill; clumsy.
examples: His inept handling of the customer's complaint only made the situation worse.
I am completely inept when it comes to assembling furniture.

words.meaning: Lack of fairness or justice.
examples: The new law aims to address the systemic inequity in the healthcare system.
Protesters were marching against social and economic inequity.

words.meaning: The quality of being free from error.
examples: Some people believe in the literal inerrancy of their holy scriptures.
The scientist questioned the supposed inerrancy of the previous study's conclusions.

words.meaning: Lacking the ability or strength to move; lacking active chemical properties.
examples: He lay there, an inert figure on the sofa, after the exhausting marathon.
Helium is an inert gas, which means it does not react with other elements.

words.meaning: Too great to calculate.
examples: The historical artifacts in the museum are of inestimable value.
Her contribution to the success of the project was inestimable.

words.meaning: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
examples: After the company's huge losses, job cuts were inevitable.
Change is an inevitable part of life.

words.meaning: Impossible to stop or prevent.
examples: The inexorable advance of the glacier reshaped the landscape.
He pleaded with his father, but the decision was inexorable.

words.meaning: Impossible to disentangle or separate.
examples: The country's economic problems are inextricable from its political instability.
He found himself caught in an inextricable web of lies.

words.meaning: Incapable of making mistakes or being wrong.
examples: No human is infallible; everyone makes mistakes.
He had an infallible memory for names and faces.

words.meaning: Well known for some bad quality or deed.
examples: The dictator was infamous for his cruelty.
The town is infamous for its high crime rate.

words.meaning: To deduce or conclude (information) from evidence and reasoning rather than from explicit statements.
examples: From her tone of voice, I could infer that she was not happy with the news.
Scientists can infer the composition of a star by analyzing its light.

words.meaning: To enter or gain access to (an organization, place, etc.) surreptitiously and gradually, especially in order to acquire secret information.
examples: The spy was trained to infiltrate the enemy's command center.
The reporter managed to infiltrate the secret meeting.

words.meaning: Extremely small.
examples: The chance of winning the grand prize was infinitesimal.
An atom is an infinitesimal particle of matter.

words.meaning: Easily set on fire.
examples: Gasoline is a highly inflammable liquid and must be handled with care.
Warning signs indicated that the warehouse contained inflammable materials.

words.meaning: Caused (something unpleasant or painful) to be suffered by someone or something.
examples: The hurricane inflicted widespread damage on the coastal communities.
The wounds inflicted during the battle were severe.

words.meaning: An arrival or entry of large numbers of people or things.
examples: The small town experienced a sudden influx of tourists during the festival.
There has been a huge influx of foreign investment into the country's tech sector.

words.meaning: To give (someone) facts or information; to give an essential or formative principle or quality to.
examples: Please inform your manager of any changes to your schedule.
His deep-seated values inform every decision he makes.

words.meaning: A violation or infringement of a law, agreement, or set of rules.
examples: He received a ticket for a minor traffic infraction.
Any infraction of the school's code of conduct will result in disciplinary action.

words.meaning: To fill or pervade; to soak in liquid to extract the flavor or healing properties.
examples: The coach's passionate speech infused the team with confidence.
To make the herbal tea, infuse the dried leaves in hot water for five minutes.

words.meaning: (Of a person) clever, original, and inventive.
examples: She came up with an ingenious solution to the complicated problem.
He built an ingenious device out of spare parts.

words.meaning: An innocent or unsophisticated young woman, especially in a play or film.
examples: The actress was often typecast as the sweet, wide-eyed ingenue.
Her first major role was that of a naive ingenue from the countryside who moves to the big city.

words.meaning: The quality of being clever, original, and inventive.
examples: It took a great deal of ingenuity to solve the complex puzzle.
The engineer was praised for her ingenuity in designing the fuel-efficient engine.
